Crown Clothing

Crown Clothing is a web app where users can browse different products across five different sections. Users can log in or signup with their email and password. Authentication using Google is also available. They can add as many items as they want to their cart and then checkout. At the checkout stage, they can use stripe to pay. You can access the app by going to this link Crown Clothing App. It might take a bit of time to load so please be paitent. Thank you.

To build this frontend application I used the following tools:

React

React Router

Heroku

JSON

S.C

Github

Stripe

When working on this application I performed the following tasks. This a high-level overview because I don't want to bore you with all the details.
     
  • Creating reusable components using JSX.
  • Constantly committing code to Github.
  • Thinking about where to store data and how to pass it to different components.
  • Using Sass to create custom designs.
  • Integrating the app with a Firebase backend.
  • Finding different libraries to use so that various technical problems can be solved.
  • Creating a well organized folder structure so that I could easily keep track of various files.
  • Using Heroku to deploy the app once it was finished.

When building this application I faced several functionality-related issues. Below you will find a list of the challenges I faced and how I solved them.

Challenge 1

Signing in is always a tedious task. If not implemented correctly users can get fade up with having to sign in constantly.

Solution 1

To make this task less tedious I implemented authentication with Google. Users can sign in using Google and that way they don’t have to worry about usernames and passwords. Our app uses Firebase which makes Google authentication easier.

Challenge 2

Constantly being aware of the users authentication status is crucial. But we don’t want to refresh the application everytime we want to check the authentication status. Constant reloads are frustrating and will distract the user from the current task they are performing.

Solution 2

The best way to handle this is to set up a subscription that serves as real-time communication between our app and Firebase. Without reloading the component or the app we can get notifications anytime the user’s auth status changes. Firebase provides a built-in method for this.

Challenge 3

Persisting user data across browser refresh. If we lose user data across browser refresh it will lead to a bad user experience.

Solution 3

Use redux-persist to save parts of user data in local storage

Challenge 4

Querying is a big part of any application. Users will want to search for something and that searching needs to be optimized so that users can quickly get their result and move on. Long response times lead to bad user experiences.

Solution 4

Data normalization helps to speed up the query process by saving data in objects instead of arrays. Objects have a time complexity of O(1) which is constant time. But arrays have a time complexity of O(n) which is linear time. Therefore objects are faster to query than arrays. So I changed the shop data to be an object instead of an array.

Challenge 5

Handling money is a big part of any e-commerce app. But it is hard to do on your own. The technical and legal aspects of online payments are so complex. Therefore you need a third-party solution.

Solution 5

Stripe is known for simplifying the payment process on the web. Using a library called react-stripe-checkout I was able to easily integrate Stripe into the app.

 

This was my first time using React to build a feature-rich frontend application. Below you will find a list of the five most important lessons I learned working on this app.

  • Managing the flow of data is complex.
  • React is a very flexible library and it can easily be combined with multiple third-party tools.
  • Breaking down components as much as possible speeds up the development process.
  • Handling authentication will always be hard but we can use social login to make the process easier.
  • Frontend developers should be familiar with at least one database system/platform.

Applications are never complete and therefore there is always room for improvement. In the future, I plan on improving the app by implementing the following strategies.

  • Make the layout more responsive so that it looks good on various screen sizes.
  • Improve security on the frontend as well as the backend.
  • Add a feature that allows users to share an item of clothing they like via social media.
  • Speed up the initial load time of the application
